response.answer_text: I had millions of dollars from selling a business and then I lost it all. I lost home. I had the IRS all over me. Then I lost my family. Then all my relationships fell apart. My friends and family from the year 2000 no longer talk to me. I take that back. One friend from the year 2000. I built back up. Built another business. Sold it. Bought another house. Then lost the money and lost the house. Lost my friends. I changed my definition of success. This is my new definition: CONNECTION: Being with people I love who love me. NO TOXIC PEOPLE. For better or worse, I have a “one strike and you’re out” policy. We wear this bag of skin for only so long.COMPETENCE: Find the things I love, get good at them, even a little bit, every day.FREEDOM: When I do something I don’t want to do, I feel resentment, I don’t do a good job, people get upset, and I lose track of who I am. If you don’t make the choices in your own life then someone else will and the results won’t be as good for you.This is hard to do. It’s not about “ building good habits”. I put that in quotes because so many bullshit self-help writers think it’s about habits. A “habit” is “make the bed” or “brush your teeth every day.” And it’s not about goals. Again, many self-help gurus say “have big goals”. “Think big or die small”. Blah blah. This is BS also. If all you have is a big goal you’re guaranteed to not make it. When I was going to shoot myself in the head I started to figure out what was important to me. And ever since then I’ve had success. In the past few years I’ve written many bestselling books. I’ve built an almost $100 million in revs. business that’s still growing. I have great friends that I love. My family is better than ever. I have a podcast that’s had over 70,000,000 downloads. And, my biggest achievement: I’m a Top Quora Writer for five years in a row. I’m in control of most of the decisions of my life. And I’m ok with the decisions I have no control over (it’s raining today, for instance, so I have a raincoat). I have a cough today but I’m carrying cough drops. I hope it gets better. But I don’t care. I’m looking forward to going to the hex game cafe later and playing board games.  I’m sick of interviewing billionaires and world champions. So boring. They all say the same things. But they speak the language of success. I’ve learned so much by interviewing them. None of what they say is a surprise. But actually putting it to work and seeing the results right in front of me is proof that these ideas, these processes they put in place, have worked for them. They’ve worked for me also. But I think I’m a little lazy. I like to bingewatch TV also.  A) VALUES: What do you stand for? I ask this to people and they say stupid shit like, “I want to help entrepeneurs succeed”. Or, “I want to help people communicate better.” I don’t mean to be harsh. But really check yourself to see if anyone gives a shit about what you say. For me: I want to be honest with the people around me. I want to do the things in life that I love (and that changes almost every day). And when I say I will do something: I overpromise and then deliver. That beats out the people who think they are smart by “underpromising”. That’s the strategy of a loser. I want to be healthy and creative. I want to entertain. I want to raise children to be good adults. I want desperately to not care what people think about me. I want to treat people with grace and respect and not care about the consequences. If I help myself, share how I do it in an entertaining way, then I can hope for the best. Oh, and whatever I am interested in: I want to be a threat.  B) PERSISTENCE If you improve 1% a day at the things you love, then very quickly you find obstacles. 1% a day equals 3800% in a year when compounding. How do you improve? “Plus, Minus, Equal”. This was told to me by the greatest ultimate fighting champion ever: Frank Shamrock. Find your Plus: a mentor or group of mentors, even if they are virtual (an author, someone on Youtube, etc). Find your Equals: people who are moving up the chain with you that you can compare notes with. Find your Minus: people who you can teach to. If you can’t teach, then you don’t understand what you’re supposed to be teaching.  (with former MMA world champion Frank Shamrock) Business is a great example. Some people are great at building a one million dollar business. But at ten million in revenues, there are a different set of problems. And at $100,000,000 there is a greater set of problems. Success means viewing problems as opportunities for solutions. In business, relationships, family, friendships, writing, art, etc. If you don’t have problems to persist through then you’ve stopped getting better and life will get worse.  C) PATIENCE I’ve asked 400 of the most successful people in the world what they did when they were at their worst. How did you survive? Almost always the answer is: WAIT. Keep being healthy. Keep writing down ideas. Keep being honest and helping friends and doing good. But don’t force anything in your career or life. Henry Winkler (the actor who played “The Fonz” on Happy Days in the 70s), told me during his NINE dark years of no acting that the worst thing he could have done was force it. Instead, he kept his network alive. He learned how to produce and direct. And gradually he got back into acting. Last season, on “Barry”, he helped that show get 13 Emmies. When you thrash, you crash. Just be quiet. Don’t move too much. Be calm. Be patient. Life rewards the patient.  (me and “The Fonz” at the comedy club, Standup NY, I am part-owner of). D) READY. FIRE. AIM Sara Blakely, the wealthiest self made woman in the world (she created Spanx) got her first big order and had only a few weeks to deliver. The problem: she didn’t have a manufacturer. So she found one. She was lit on fire and had to put that fire out. So many people plan plan plan. Analysis paralysis. Have the idea. Get the order. Then figure it out. Want to swim. Get thrown in the water. Don’t drown. Have a story. Write it down. Then edit the grammar and make a second, third, fourth draft of the story. Richard Branson didn’t buy 10 airplanes and then start Virgin Air. He called Boeing, convinced them to LEND him a plane for a year. Then got a route from the US to England. THEN started Virgin Air, which he sold for billions.  (Sara built Spanx (example in the image) into a multi-billion business without any fashion experience. She just wanted to help women feel better) E) OBSESSION When you love something, you’ll WANT to do it in every spare moment. You’ll read about it. You’ll watch videos. Get mentors. Talk about it with friends. Study the nuances. Start trying it for yourself. And on and on. The one who is obsessed will beat out the person who is not obsessed. Why? Simple: the person who is not obsessed will NEVER know the nuance and subtleties. I once started a business that combined my interests in writing, investing, and programming. All my prior obsessions. Three months into developing my idea I realized I had a ton of competition. But I could tell they weren’t obsessed. They weren’t a threat. I got millions of users with a month. I sold my company for $10,000,000. They all went out of business. Nobody can beat an obsessive.  (Sasha Cohen told me only obsession is what got her a medal in the 2006 Olympics) F) TALENT SEX Scott Adams, the creator of Dilbert, told me, “I’m pretty good at drawing, but not the best. I’m pretty good at writing, but not the best. I’m pretty funny, but not the best, and I’m pretty good at business, but not the best. But I’m probably the best at the combination.” Which is why Dilbert is the top selling syndicated cartoon strip and Scott is probably worth over $100,000,000. When you get pretty good at a lot of things and then combine them: you’ll be among the best in the world at the intersection. List your talents. Start figuring out how to combine them.  (Dilbert) G) VISION Don’t read the news. Read a lot of books by smart people. Here are some starting points: Sapiens by Yuval Harari The Evolution of Everything by Matt Ridley Antifragile by Nassim Taleb Zero to One by Peter Thiel Tiny Beautiful Things by Cheryl Strayed Thinking in Bets by Annie Duke Look around the world. Don’t listen to the people who are screaming and yelling and hating and fighting. Think realistically about what you love doing: where will it be five years from now? For instance, is the 2 party system in America going to last? Will TV shows still be 30 minutes or 60 minutes? Will bookstores exist? Will Uber still exist? Will AI be doing surgeries? Have a vision for where the world is going. Or wait for one (see above). Vision is the mother of invention. H) PERSUASION Every successful person I know, knows how to persuade. Robert Cialdini’s book “Influence” is the Bible of persuasion techniques. BUT, Vision + Obsession + Health makes it easy to persuade others. I) EMPATHY Rule #3 of improvisation is: “Make your scene partner look good.” Nobody gives a shit about you. Stop caring so much about what people think you. Focus on how to make the people around you look good. Then the world around you will look good. Then the center of the world around you will look good. I mean..you.  J) PROBLEM SOLVING get a waiter’s padevery day write down ten ideasWithin six months you will be an idea machine. People will throw problems at you and you will be able to solve them trivially. This is a super power. And with great power becomes great responsibility.  On the TV show “Crashin”, Pete Holmes asks the famous comedian Whitney Cummings, “Can you give me advice? What does it take to succeed?” I love her response. First she said, “I can’t tell you. There’s no answer.” And he begged. “Please just tell me one thing “ She said, “The star is the person everyone else wants to be friends with.”

How does one succeed in life? Most people think the truth to success are like this Is this the answers you were looking for? I’d hope not. You must work hard or work smartPerseveranceA flare of knowledge or giftedness leading to successYou must be proactive, social, have “confidence” or create effort“Learn from mistakes and failures”You see none of what is listed is true in fact far from it. So how does one succeed in life? The truth is we actually: Don’t know. Most people think they know the answers or truth to how someone succeeds but it’s quite rare to live a life successfully, if it’s even possible. How does one succeed in life? Sacrifices, failures and not so much learning from them but refining, developing and implementing a plan to do better the next time around. This may or may not in reality guarantee success, the hours or efforts you put in don’t matter either. In reality here’s what it actually takes to be successful in life.  It could look something like this, and most people assume in linear progression, but that’s far from true if not true at all. Real success and real improvement in life takes a combination of many things, there will be times you don’t always improve, there will be times of struggle, obstacles, failures and difficulties that come your way. In real life, there’s no set age that you need to have something accomplished by, even if you start business or you plan to do social marketing or have effective strategies to work on your website or your physical business, it could also look something like this as well. Think of how many businesses out there that eventually run out of business or they once were successful but ended up losing business over time? I will also show the realities that “success” isn’t really success at all, but it’s learned through trial and error, mistakes made in your efforts and failed plans that are effective but just didn’t go through with you.  Now you might be thinking, how could the most successful people in the world be wrong about success? And it’s because the truth is not everyone will have the same results the next person had on their experiences or journeys in life. A good example is you could be like JK Rowling, and write a novel, but you will never have exactly her life and have the same exact results she had with Harry Potter Novels. What Bill Gates went through is his own story and nobody else’s. You can’t copy exactly somebody else’s life, you could have the same talents or skills as them, work just as hard but due to the support, fans and loyalty they have, it may not work for you in the same ways it worked for them. You’re not always going to get results no matter how hard you try because it isn’t your fault at all, it’s the reality of implementing that plan or strategy into your game-plan and thinking it’s always going to lead to results. You will experience ups and downs, twist and turns, as well as a longer time to get the results that you want. You see you and so many people have been lied to by the internet. If it were true that you could also reap the results you want every time you put effort or hard work into something, everybody would be out of poverty and the economy would improve in no time but that’s just not the case. You will deal with pain, emotional stress or overload before you’re given just some results due to working smart or hard. You will need to fight your way through life in order to get what you want. If you think i’m wrong take a look at this musician below. Playing the guitar until your hands are bleeding and that also is painful. Think of what they go through before you vision some illusionary view of success which doesn’t exist in reality.  Now it’s true we all must learn from mistakes and failures, but this also doesn’t guarantee results either, it can either work for you or it won’t but even if the plan is just slight improvement than before, you can get there but time and patience is the only thing that will get you to your next goal. If the truth was so simple, we’d all be successful entrepreneurs and businessmen making millions per year just by hard work alone. If it’s sports for example and you want to be faster, stronger and better than before, that’s going to take a long time before you start seeing even the smallest improvements in yourself. The truth isn’t always the truth for everyone as well, few people make it to the top and you can have equal talent, measures and efforts to people’s favorites in life, but for most people it isn’t going to get them anywhere. For every actor, musician or talk-show host you see on TV, there’s also the majority who have failed to get a spot. You also need to realize how rare it actually is to be talented, skilled or a top performer in society. This could be dreams of getting into a great college, great career or in athletics.  Why you shouldn’t care if someone is successful or not? The people we look up to as idols or those who are in respectable careers (scientists, lawyers, politicians, engineers), are in the few and far in between. Not everybody is meant for college or worldwide success. If it were true that success was that easy to accomplish by working hard or putting in the effort, we’re also missing many other counterparts to being successful as well. To do well in school you’d need to study but to perform at a very high, top tier competitive level takes more than just a flare or a knack for studying. People seem to think they know all the reasons for success but will realize that in due part to having a successful internet business, Youtube/business channel, or physical business, while earning enough money to make it into a career, takes being in the high performers which is in the top 0.1%, 2% or 14%. The real answer comes down to one thing which is do you have what it takes to be successful? I also think it ties down not to hard work, or talent or some mutant gene that makes someone better than the rest of the population, but the questions instead. Do you have what it takes to accept risks, failures, plateaus and a huge learning curve to avoid such mistakes in order to learn, grow and go from plan A to plan B? Do you have what it takes? Businesses take risks and huge steps toward improvement (investments and creativity). Are you willing to not be the “average” and do things that are uncomfortable to your well-being? Are you willing to study, learn or do things that not everyone else is doing? The real truth to success The more money you want to make the harder it’s going to be plain and simple. All the social marketing, squeezing the bar or weights until your veins pop out, or implementing social media marketing/having the best editing, social groups and marketing plans aren’t going to do you jack if you don’t realize the reality of it all. If it was true that we all had the answers, all of us would be reaping the rewards of success, we’d all be top athletes, scholars, top scientists or doctors from around the world or world known actors, social-media entertainers, exc. Take it from someone who serves a huge example in the world, one of the best NBA players of all time.  But… after all that’s why you shouldn’t give up. Accept failure/mistakes with an open mind. The next time you are criticized or even reminded by those who don’t like you or think negatively about you, just know that you’re not alone in failing, in fact some of the best people in the world who have reached worldwide success, have had to learn from failures and mistakes so much it’s their career. What people should think instead.. Not every adult or young adult 20–30 years old has got their “life together or in order” according to you or what other people think. In fact you’re not alone in failing or not getting the results that you’d like despite all of your efforts, that’s why life is very real and not something to not be taken seriously. That’s why you need to cherish the small results or even accept the position you’re in now and people will also respect that about you. If it means being median your whole life, that’s a good start to be in, taking small steps toward victory is better than missing a whole bunch of steps (setting your goals too high), and tripping over yourself. What do you have to lose when becoming successful? Everything. You put your life on the line, including yourself, your finances, your failures/struggles, your own investments, the only way is to combat with your talents and to continue no matter what. Can you succeed in life? You could just be aware of all factors and obstacles that come your way. Don’t assume this response is from pessimism or negative thinking it’s not but showing you what anyone could go through during their journeys to success in life.

The miracle of success is that the smallest step towards success attracts more success! Here is a very brief outline of key points for achieving highest level of success. Look into the nearest mirror- The person staring back at you is the only person responsible for your success.Smile back at your reflection- Successful people are cheerful, optimistic and forward thinking. Smile! Positive thinking drives out negative thoughts. Its hard to have a negative thought while smiling.Have positive self esteem- Feel good about yourself and your abilities, achievements and potential. Remind and praise yourself with your past accomplishments.Believe in yourself- God doesn't make extras just to fill the scenery. You are here for a purpose. Find your mission and begin working on it.Desire to be successful- Desire to be success and commit to be success.Associate with successful people- When faced with choices, do what a successful person will do.Avoid negative people- Negative people are toxic, they destroy and don't build. The odds are greater that they will pull you down faster than you can lift them up. Avoid all the whiners, complainers, blamers and thumb suckers.Do what you are best at- Do not stay stuck doing things that are frustrating, boring, unhealthy, unproductive, demeaning or unfulfilling.Write down a vision- Everyday visualize yourself as you would like to be and then act that way!Write down your biggest goal- Success is the result of a personal decision, so start your goal with “I”. Read your goal aloud everyday.Study the science of success- read books, listen to tapes, watch videos and positive TV programmes.Everyday do something that brings you closer to your goal- Never give up. You can only fail if you quit trying. Achieving success requires following a system .Put these key points into practice and see yourself succeed.

Most people don’t realize the difference between success and failure is often very small. If you were headed to the moon and were off just 1 degree, you'd miss your target by 4,169 miles. Simply by changing one’s attitude, working smart, and giving a solid effort, you can achieve amazing results that, otherwise, would seem impossible. Just think, by simply adjusting your course in a positive manner, you can set the odds in your favor to achieve your goals. Here are seven key tips that can tilt the balance in your favor. Focus on continuous improvement. Winners are always looking to find ways to improve their skills and knowledge. The opportunity to keep growing and learning is a lifelong process. You can always get better!Never be satisfied with temporary accomplishments. The moment you think you’ve made it is the moment you’ve failed. Why? Complacency sets in, and you lose the fire inside. Success is only temporary, and you can never take it for granted.Look to lift up those around you. Winners know that teamwork helps achieve big goals. Success happens when you elevate everyone around you. You can’t do it alone.Don’t blame others. Those who focus on making excuses create negativity. Instead of thinking that everyone else is holding you back, focus on what you can do to move ahead and better yourself.Don’t waste time. Winners don’t waste valuable time doing frivolous things that take focus away from their goals. While others party, watch TV, and play video games, winners are pushing ahead on their mission to succeed.Love the process. You have to enjoy the process of achieving the small victories and working to become successful. It will often take more time than you realize, but you have to relish the hard work and the climb. The victory is in the journey.Don’t quit. Many people have amazing talents and skills they don’t even realize exist. They fail because they never even try or they quit too soon. Learning to overcome challenges and perseverence is often the difference between reaching your goals or falling short.

Find yourself. With all of the noise put out there, we are buried in rubble.  For example, money is one thing. Most of us follow the money until we figure out it is a trap. It is necessary, but are we really happy? For now, I am giving you two options.  1. Figure yourself out. Find out who you are. I know you said you have no idea about your strengths or your passions, but that's your problem. You don't know who you are. You need to know yourself to market yourself and feel confident. Note the things that make you tick. You mentioned finance and investing. That's a start. But really dig down deep into who you are. Don't start classifying yourself. I don't believe in that BS. Extrovert or introvert. Hell, sometimes I'm an introvert and sometimes I'm an extrovert. Classifying yourself is not only a waste of time, but I find it stressful. There is no category, only your individual self. Volunteer. Yes, I said it. I know you are struggling at your work, but believe me, you can really find a peace in volunteering. It really blows off some steam. You meet new people and discover things about yourself you never knew about yourself. I never have done taxes before in my life and I volunteered at VITA (Volunteer Income Tax Association) and even though I didn't enjoy it, it helped me with a tax class I'm taking now. I volunteered to teach old people to type. I thought it was going to be dry, but I enjoyed helping. And better yet, it felt good helping other people. Get a part time job on the weekend to help you pocket some extra cash for future uses, or additional investing. It's probably nothing compared to what you are making now, but it is better than wasting time reading about things you can only hope for. You will definitely enjoy your free time more. Work at a McDonalds, Dunkin Donuts, or be a waiter. Anything you do, do not sit still and do nothing.  I know this is a generalization, but hey, there is no step by step guide to life. I'm happy there isn't. Imagine how dull life would be if you had a step by step guide (I bet you're thinking "Fuck you, you have no idea..." but come on. The point of life is for times like these. I know you must have seen the Matrix.    Your second option is starting fresh. If you have yourself figured out, start taking online classes. Make sure that the online university is credible, but more importantly, make sure you know what you are doing is what you are interested in. It sounds like you are not interested in what you do. Whatever new thing you start to study, it must be better than what you are currently doing because it sounds like you are pretty miserable (I can definitely relate even though I am not done with school yet). If you can't afford it, start a new chapter in your life. Join the military. When you're done serving, get another education (you would deserve it by then). Don't completely scrap what you already know as knowledge can only help you down the road. Or leave everything behind, and join the peace corps or whatever. Whatever you do, it is your decision based on your judgment. So don't blame anything on me. I don't mean to put any pressure on you, but there really is no pressure. Who cares about mistakes? Learn from your mistakes and your mistakes won't be wasted. Life is not about a job. Life is not about any of this rat race BS. If you believe it is, hey, I'm not stopping you (I'm most likely going to be a part of the rat race one day too). But don't be stressed from the material things in life. It's interesting what a couple of people you love can do. If you have friends, chill with them some more. If you don't, start making friends (another word for networking). Don't worry. Be happy.It's a big world bud. Think larger than a cubicle.(You sound like an entrepreneur with nothing to lose but hope still holding on)Don't let the little things in life get you down. The other parts of your question: There's no secret to gaining a competitive advantage. Find out what separates you from the better performers. If they are smarter, here's your chance to read something useful (the monotone of the internet text makes this sound mean but in no way am I trying to be mean).  Ambition? Simple, always try your hardest. I have always tried hard hard in my life, and never have I regretted it. Statistics or general math? No idea. It's not my field to decide. Recap: Never stop trying your hardest. Never stop discovering yourself. Never stop moving. I know you can do it man. There are 7 freekin billion people in this world, and we are still surviving.

How does one succeed in life? Do the opposite of what most people do  The world is full of AVERAGE. Average people. Average service. Average products. Average relationships. Average businesses. Average attitudes. Average lives. If you were to simply do the opposite of what the average person, business, or product does, you could become outrageously successful. What does this look like in practical terms? Let`s dive in. Don`t get a university education or degree  Read this carefully: YOU DO NOT NEED A UNIVERSITY DEGREE OR QUALIFICATION TO SUCCEED IN LIFE! Unfortunately, we have been indoctrinated into the belief that the more successful amongst us are those that are `properly` educated. We are taught that to get a `good` job we need to slog our way through textbooks and exams for 3–4 years, on top of the 12 years we have already had at the primary and secondary level, to get a piece of paper that says we are worth something. Not to mention that. on top of all that, we must saddle ourselves with enormous financial debt in the form of student loans to get through a basic degree, which we then spend years paying off! And yet, if we look at some of the most successful people that ever lived, an interesting pattern emerges amongst a lot of them. A vast number of them neither have a university degree, nor even finished university! Some never even went!! Both Steve Jobs and Bill Gates were college dropouts! Even other outrageously successful entrepreneurs like Richard Branson, Michael Dell, Henry Ford, and Mary Kay Ash don`t have degrees. For some professions, medicine and being classic examples, a tertiary education is a must have. Beyond that, university degrees don`t guarantee you success, much less a job! I have THREE degrees in Education, History, and Politics. Not ONE of them has led to a guaranteed job. In fact, I have had to move countries in order to get some meaningful employment!! Save your money and, more importantly, your time. Go out and get some real life experiences and explore your world while you are still young Don`t get a J.O.B. (Just Over Broke)  Hear me out. This does go against conventional wisdom. But, if you want an extraordinary life, you have to what is NOT conventional. The vast majority of people in the workforce HATE what they do. They work simply for the money. Their existence revolves around their job and they spend what little time they have away from their desks and cubicles drowning their sorrows in alcohol, drugs, television, the Internet, and meaningless conversation. Is this how you want to spend your life??? If your answer is `Hell no!`, and I hope it is, then you need to ditch the idea of getting a job for the money and living just to make a paycheck and scrape by. Instead you could do one of two very important and vaulable things: 1.Start a business that fulfills a need Got a problem that needs solving? Can you find a way to tackle a dilemma that a lot of people are having right now? Create a service or product that can solve that and monetize it. Can`t think of anything? Write out some problems you have in life that have not been solved by big business or anyone else. Get creative and find solutions to the worlds problems. 2. Turn your passion into a side hustle or full-time business Are you so passionate about something that you just can`t live without it? Or, do you have something that lights you up when you talk about it? Why not make some money from it? Find a way to make that passion profitable. You only have one life. You might as well do something that you are interested in or that you love. I am NOT saying that these paths will be easy! They involve a lot of risk and a lot of faith in yourself and your abilities. Think of it this way: If you were to die tomorrow, would you rather die doing what you love, or what someone else wants you to do? Don`t spend your free time buried in screens, TV, drugs, and alcohol  It is important to have some down time. You DO need a break from the everyday grind. But, most people spend FAR TOO MUCH time sedating themselves. Most people are far too comfortable picking up a beer than a book. Most people are more inclined to listen to the TV than a teacher. In short, most people pick the EASY ROUTE. But, as Les Brown said, `Do what is easy and your life will be hard. Do what is hard and your life will be easy!` Spend as much of your private and free time as possible working on developing yourself: Get to the gym.Read a book.Start a personal passion project.Start a new business on the side.Learn a new skill.Read a newspaper.Clean your house and get your workspace tidied up.Use the time you have wisely. One day you will run out of that time. I hope when that time comes that you can look back and be proud of what you did. Don`t choose to be UNHAPPY  So many of us make ourselves unhappy on purpose. We always feel like we don`t deserve anything or that everything that happens to us is everybody else`s fault. We don`t even realise the damage that we do to ourselves every day. Instead, we seek to live out someone else`s narrative. We want to live another person`s life because ours are simply not good enough. Why does it have to be this way? It doesn`t !!!! You can choose to be happy right now. You can take responsibility for your life right now. It is YOUR life!!! Sure, bad things happen to us. They happen to ALL of us! Life isn`t fair and it gives us a crappy hand sometimes. SO WHAT??? Are you just going to sit there and wallow in your sorry state like everybody else??? Get up!! Get moving! Start building a life that you want. Ignore what others are doing. Find the magic in your own existence and work on yourself constantly, moving toward the best version of yourself. Taking this simple step alone will separate you from 90% of the population immediately. Don`t wake up late, or 10 minutes before you have to do something  Most successful people have a morning routine. They have gotten more done in the early hours of the morning than most people get done all day. This is achieved by committing to waking up early, usually around dawn, or even before it, and having a system in place for getting a number of tasks done during the quietest and most peaceful times of the day. The average person lumbers out of bed with their alarms, all groggy from the lack of sleep from the night before, eats an unhealthy breakfast and just makes it in time for the daily commute to a job they can`t stand. What would your day be like if you got up an hour or two earlier and practiced a few new skills or did some exercise? You would be way more successful. You would be more energetic, more focused, and ready to take the day on Don`t sleepwalk through your mornings like the average human. Dedicate yourself to a solid morning routine and get moving.  Remember, if you want an extraordinary life, you need to do extraordinary things. That means doing the opposite of average people. Take the leap. Yesterday I saw by chance on TV the last part of a movie that serves as a metaphor for triumph and failure in life. Two of the best martial arts fighters happen to meet in the Chinatown of San Francisco: Bruce Lee and a Buddhist monk who has just arrived from China, exiled, and who works as a dishwasher in a restaurant. In Chinatown a triad of gangsters kidnaps the fiancée of a promoter of combats to force this one to organize a combat between those two cracks. The promoter manages to convince the monk and Lee. Among the shady deals of the triad are the bets, and a fight like that will bring them great economic benefits, hence their interest. The combat is celebrated. Lee is not yet the world-famous Bruce Lee. He has an aggressive spirit. While the monk is eminently a teacher who wants to teach Lee the philosophy of martial arts, which is not about attacking but defending. The concept of victory and defeat does not exist for the monk, or has a very different meaning. Lee learns that from the monk in the course of the combat, which ends in a draw: no winner, no loser. This result is a bad business for the triad that demands to know who has been the winner. Then Lee learns that the life of the girlfriend of the combat promoter is at stake, and goes to the restaurant where the monk works. Both face the triad and demand the boss to free the girl. The boss in turn demands that one of them declare himself the winner and the other accept his defeat: a lot of money is at stake in bets. However, for the monk and for Lee (who has learned that from the monk), the notion of winning or losing does not make sense, it is not important. The monk declares winner to Lee. But Lee does not accept his victory: he demands the liberation not only of the kidnapped girl but of all the other girls that the triad has kidnapped. The boss agrees, and only then Lee agrees to declare himself the winner. The "moral" of this story seems to me as follows: Mostly, in our society, to succeed is to have a prosperous and happy life (win the combat). While, for the true sage, to succeed in life has a very different meaning: it is doing good, helping people in need (rescuing kidnapped girls).
